For more reading on the topic of bananas and Fukushima, I reccomend this [1] article, written at the time of the accident, that explains things in a thorough and intelligent manner.

Author: m_ram
Content: My Mom had a bunch of old AutoCAD files on Zip Disks that she needed to sort through a few years ago. Her Zip Drive was a parallel port model and she no longer had a computer with a parallel port. I bought a used USB model for about $20 on eBay and she got all of her files back. These drives were amazing for their time, but I can't believe people are still using them regularly.

Author: FoeNyx
Content:
I don't think it's comparable: the tsunami did not create a 20 km exclusion zone contaminated for the decades to come.

We may be safe overseas and it can be an epsilon on Nature's power scale but it can not be reduced as 'negligible' for the thousands of people who used to live there.

Author: da_maire
Content:
I knew things were going south with Evernote when they added a store that sells fucking socks and backpacks while the Mac client still couldn't edit existing tables in documents. The table editing limitation was eventually fixed but much more serious problems have since cropped up.

Sync issues and the unusably slow iOS client caused me to drop it for personal use a few months ago, now it's relegated to only work notes with the desktop client. For this really basic purpose it's alright, it has a few major annoyances and the interface has gotten much worse over the years but it'd be too much effort to migrate to something else and keep my tags/notebooks.

This is not a healthy relationship I have with Evernote Corporation. I committed to their product but they didn't commit to me.
